learning_objectives: Understand that light travels in straight lines.
Differentiate between opaque, transparent, and translucent objects based on how light passes through them.
Explain and demonstrate how shadows are formed when light is blocked by an opaque object.
Describe how a pinhole camera works using the principle that light travels in straight lines.
key_concepts: Transparent objects allow light to pass through completely
Translucent objects allow some light to pass through, scattering it
Shadows form in the region where light is blocked
Pinhole cameras form inverted images due to straight-line light travel
user_interactions: Slider to adjust light source angle (0° to 180°)
Slider to adjust light source distance from object
Dropdown to select object shape (hand, ball, book)
Button to toggle between shadow formation and pinhole camera modes
Slider to adjust screen distance from object
simulation_logic: Initialize scene with light source, object, and screen in vertical layout
Display light rays as straight lines from source to object
For opaque objects: show complete shadow region behind object where no light reaches
For transparent objects: show light rays passing straight through with no shadow
For translucent objects: show scattered light rays and faint shadow
In pinhole camera mode: replace object with pinhole and show inverted image formation on screen
Update shadow size and sharpness based on light source position and object distance
Provide instant visual feedback for all user interactions
mobile_ui_plan: Top banner with topic title and brief description
Interactive simulation canvas taking 60% of screen height
Control panel below canvas with stacked vertical controls
Information panel at bottom showing current concept explanation
Responsive design that adapts to different screen sizes
Large touch-friendly buttons and sliders for mobile interaction
misconceptions_to_address: Shadows are always black (show they can be gray for translucent objects)
Light bends around objects (emphasize straight-line travel)
Transparent objects create shadows (demonstrate they don't)
Shadow size is always same as object size (show it changes with distance)
text_instructions_for_students: Welcome! This simulation helps you understand light and shadows.
Use the controls to change the light, object, and screen positions.
Try different object types to see how they affect light and shadows.
Click 'Pinhole Camera' to see how cameras work using light principles.
Experiment with different settings and observe what happens!
safety_constraints: No bright flashing lights or rapid color changes
Use soft, non-glaring colors suitable for mobile screens
Ensure text is large enough to read on small screens
Avoid any content that could trigger photosensitive reactions
Include accessibility labels for screen readers
